awd_titl_txt: Mitochondrial effects on male and female fitness in the copepod Tigriopus californicus
awd_abstract_narration:
This project tests the hypothesis that mutations that harm males, can accumulate in parts of the genome, the mitochondria, that are inherited only through the female line. These male-harming mutations are not removed because the effects of natural selection acting on males are not passed to the next generation. Most familiar organisms have a large genome that resides in the nucleus of their cells, which is inherited from both parents, plus a small genome in the mitochondria. The mitochondria are the batteries of each cell, which are inherited only from the mother. Mitochondrial gene products interact with nuclear gene products to perform critical life functions. Male-harming mutations are predicted to accumulate in the mitochondrial genome and result in their reduced fitness. The project will examine interactions between the nuclear and mitochondrial genomes and the effects on male and female fitness in a small marine shellfish, the copepod Tigriopus californicus. The results will test whether the hypothesized negative effects on male fitness are widespread and examine whether and how the nuclear-mitochondrial interactions impact these effects. This hypothesis has profound implications for sex-specific medical interventions, because harmful mitochondrial mutations are implicated in male infertility, and diseases such as diabetes, cardiomyopathy, and male deafness, as well as in the overall aging process. Beyond the research itself, the project will train a postdoctoral researcher, Ph.D. students and undergraduate researchers. Further, the project will support outreach to diverse Los Angeles communities, including collaborations with the Aquarium of the Pacific (aimed at promoting public awareness of evolution) and with university programs for middle- and high-school students (aimed at enhancing the evolution curriculum in classes serving under-represented minorities). 

Male-specific mutational load will be assessed by creating 12 cytoplasmic hybrids in which mitochondria from 12 divergent populations will each be transferred onto the same isogenic nuclear background by approximately 15 generations of backcrossing. These 12 lines will include 11 interpopulation hybrids and one control. Each of the 12 lines will be used for assays of sex-specific fertility and survivorship over the full lifespan (180+ days). These data will be used to test the magnitude of the gender gap in mitochondrial effects, to test if the gender gap is larger for fertility than longevity, and to test whether this gender gap is aggravated in later life stages and under higher metabolic demand (e.g. higher temperature). The 12 mitochondrial genomes will be fully sequenced, allowing tests of the genomic extent of mitochondrial mutations with sex-specific effects. Further, gene expression will be assessed in one interpopulation hybrid and the control to identify nuclear genes associated with sex-specific mito-nuclear conflict.

por.por_cntn:
Life in eukaryotes, which includes all organisms other than bacteria and archaea, requires tight coordination between nuclear genes (inherited from both parents) and mitochondrial genes (usually inherited from the mother). While mitochondrial genes compose only a tiny fraction of the genome, they play critical roles in energy production and protein synthesis. Because males are an evolutionary dead-end for mitochondria, mitochondrial mutations that are bad for males may still be passed if they are good or neutral for females. Males can then be expected to accumulate deleterious mitochondrial mutations, a hypothesis known as the Mother's Curse. If males are cursed with mitochondrial defects, this has major implications for conservation and for human medicine. Since strong support for the hypothesis is largely limited to studies of fruitflies, we tested the hypothesis in a different system, the copepod Tigriopus californicus. These are minute crustaceans living in splashpools on rocky outcrops along the west coast of North America. These animals are particularly well-suited to this research because they are easily raised in the lab, have fast generation times, are well characterized genetically, and lack sex chromosomes, whose sex-specific effects can be confounded with sex-specific mitochondrial effects. 

Mitochondrial effects in males and females were tested in a series of hybrid lines, including "cytoplasmic hybrids" where different mitochondrial types were placed onto the same nuclear background through a multigeneration breeding design. For this work, we developed methods to quantify gene expression in individual animals, which had not previously been done in this species due to their small size. When animals were raised at two temperatures, mitochondrial effects on fitness were amplified at the higher temperature, consistent with the prediction that mismatch between nuclear and mitochondrial genes is unmasked under higher metabolic demand. Significant sex differences in mitochondrial effects were found for a range of traits including fertility, longevity, gene expression, mitochondrial DNA copy number and DNA damage. However, these sex differences did not consistently support the Mother's Curse hypothesis. Instead, results for fertility and longevity revealed higher accumulation of deleterious mitochondrial mutations in females.

Our finding of strong sex differences in mitochondrial effects, with deleterious effects in both males and females, has important implications for conservation strategies involving translocating animals between locations, as well as for the development of sex-specific medical treatments including mitochondrial replacement therapy. The work also had broad impacts through training and outreach. Trainees supported by the grant includes 2 postdoctoral scholars, 4 Ph.D. students and 10 undergraduate researchers. Our research group also co-hosted workshops at the Aquarium of the Pacific, the largest aquarium in southern California which serves over 1.5 million visitors a year. In these workshops, scientists from USC collaborated with aquarium staff to develop strategies to promote public understanding of evolution using aquarium exhibits. Finally, the grant also supported development and implementation of a Darwin Day workshop on evolutionary biology curricula for K-12 classrooms. For this event, our research group collaborated with USC's Young Scientist's Program to present resources that local teachers can use to enhance the teaching of evolution in their classrooms.
